elements.title: Self-Evident Service Concept Card - Three-Pillar Listing Explainer
elements.description: A standalone above-the-fold card that communicates the Split Lease service model in under 5 seconds. Vince arrived at a listing page and could not understand what the service was (1:19-1:33: 'How does this work? Is it like a hotel?'). Krug's First Law demands self-evidence. This card places the three-pillar concept (your space when you are there, a matched roommate when you are not, your stuff stays) above photos and amenities using a warm surface background, three icon panels with labels, and a single-sentence value proposition. Designed for scanning, not reading. Addresses the highest-risk friction moment in the guest journey: concept confusion at first encounter.
elements.html_css_snippet:
How It Works

Your own place, 2 nights a week.

A matched roommate takes the other nights. You never overlap. Your stuff stays put.

100% Yours
The space is entirely yours on your scheduled nights
Ghost Roommate
A matched person uses it only when you are away
Your Stuff Stays
Store toiletries, monitors, everything between visits
Find Your Place Learn more

elements.title: Office-Days-to-Stay-Nights Schedule Translator
elements.description: An interactive-feeling schedule display that accepts office days as the primary input and derives stay nights automatically. Vince made a real-time translation error during his call (6:27-6:43), initially saying Monday-Tuesday when he meant Sunday-Monday nights. The agent confirmed this is systemic (6:43-6:56). Krug warns every question mark adds cognitive load. This element shows both formats simultaneously: office days prominent in purple badges, derived stay nights in muted secondary badges below, with a bridge sentence on first encounter. Monthly cost displays in monospace for data trust. Addresses the persistent schedule-to-nights cognitive burden across proposal, negotiation, and active lease phases.

elements.title: Flexibility Safety Net - Commitment-Adjacent Reassurance Callout
elements.description: A flexibility assurance callout positioned directly above a commitment button that addresses the guest's dominant anxiety: being locked into inflexible terms. Vince raised flexibility before pricing (5:06-5:25) and his schedule was unconfirmed throughout the call (0:39). Krug's visual hierarchy demands that the most important secondary information be visually prominent at the decision point. This element uses an informational blue-purple palette (not warning colors) to deliver calm reassurance. The callout content adapts per phase. This addresses the critical friction moment where schedule uncertainty prevents commitment.
elements.html_css_snippet:
Your Proposal Summary

Review your details before sending to the host.

Location Studio on Mulberry St, Nolita
Office Days Monday & Tuesday
Stay Nights Sunday & Monday
Starting ~4 weeks from now
Monthly Cost $906/mo
You are not locked in. This is your starting schedule. Change your nights anytime through the app -- no penalty, no hassle. How it works

elements.title: Satisfice-First Search Result - Single Best Match with Fallback Alternative
elements.description: A search result layout that supports satisficing behavior by presenting a single dominant recommended listing with a visually subordinate alternative below. Vince found one listing and reached out without browsing others (1:02-1:07). When told it might be unavailable, he pivoted instantly (3:52-4:02). Krug's satisficing principle: guests choose the first reasonable option. This element makes the best match 2x the visual weight of alternatives, uses a 'Best match' badge, shows monthly cost in the guest's schedule context, and includes an unavailable fallback state. Prevents dead-end dropout when the first match fails.
elements.html_css_snippet:

elements.title: Monthly-First Pricing Display with Nightly Derivation
elements.description: A pricing component that shows the monthly total as the primary, largest-type number with the nightly rate derivation below in secondary treatment. Vince asked 'how much would this cost?' (4:38) -- a monthly budget question -- but the agent could only quote a nightly rate ($113). Krug says: eliminate needless cognitive steps. The mental math of nightly x nights x weeks is a question mark the platform should eliminate. This element personalizes the monthly total to the guest's selected schedule, uses monospace for data trust, and shows how cost changes if the schedule changes. Covers the novel-concept hierarchy principle: monthly cost above nightly rate.
elements.html_css_snippet:

elements.title: Scannable Move-In Guide - Five-Card Progressive Arrival Sequence
elements.description: A mobile-first, card-based move-in guide that delivers on the 'feel like home' promise through a progressive five-card sequence matching the physical rhythm of arriving. The agent promised Vince personal storage for 'toiletries and monitors' (2:10-2:20) and 'feel like home every time.' Krug's scanning principle means Vince will NOT read a multi-page House Manual. This element uses maximum 5 cards, 20 words each, with photo-first layout and a progress indicator. The storage card (third position) operationalizes the core emotional promise. Cards follow arrival order: Access, WiFi, Storage, Kitchen, House Rules. This is a retention-critical element addressing the promise-to-reality gap at move-in.
elements.html_css_snippet:
Welcome, Vince

Everything you need for your first stay.

WiFi — Connected

Kitchen

elements.title: Proposal Status Tracker - Transparent Progress During the Wait
elements.description: A three-step status tracker that replaces the black-box wait between proposal submission and host response with transparent progress. The call ended with 'I will have myself or someone get in touch with you shortly' (6:27) -- informationally empty. Krug's muddling-through principle predicts guests will fill the information vacuum with anxious narratives. This element shows three clear steps (Sent, Under Review, Response Ready), includes the guest's specific proposal details as a reference, provides a concrete timeline estimate, and transforms passive waiting into visible forward motion. Addresses the post-submission dropout risk identified across layers.
elements.html_css_snippet:
